pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw:
My only concern is that doc tackles a _lot_ of \(or rather, more than presently useful?\) behavior \(e.g. explicit \+ implicit name scoping for composition\).

It would be nice to carve out the immediate functionality needs in a more focused fashion.

Is there a way that this can be accommodated by that design doc, or making a new design doc? \(If not, perhaps it’d be OK to just stick with the tutorial format, and then later compose it into a design doc?\)
content.html:
My only concern is that doc tackles a lot of (or rather, more than presently useful?) behavior (e.g. explicit + implicit name scoping for composition).

It would be nice to carve out the immediate functionality needs in a more focused fashion.

Is there a way that this can be accommodated by that design doc, or making a new design doc? (If not, perhaps it’d be OK to just stick with the tutorial format, and then later compose it into a design doc?)

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw: I think the tutorial describes well the current behaviour. It could also be nice to discuss what happens when a `<joint>` is a direct child of the `<world>`, which is [supported](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/21d2cbe52bbd104f24a50b0037e5b3da5657c644/sdf/1.6/world.sdf?fileviewer=file-view-default#world.sdf-58) by the spec.
content.html: I think the tutorial describes well the current behaviour. It could also be nice to discuss what happens when a <joint> is a direct child of the <world>, which is supported by the spec.

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw:
wow, I never noticed that a `<joint>` could be a child of the `<world>`. It's been there for ages, at least since libsdformat 1.4.0:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/sdformat_1.4.0/sdf/1.4/world.sdf#world.sdf-16

I don't think gazebo has ever parsed joints directly under the world. The [World::LoadEntities function](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/bd1cdea8fa3d71d6afcdaa83c9b01891d5f72e71/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#World.cc-1167) certainly doesn't.

Have you ever seen one in a world file? I can add a note for it in the document, but I don't think it really counts as a legacy behavior if it's never actually been used.
content.html:
wow, I never noticed that a <joint> could be a child of the <world>. It's been there for ages, at least since libsdformat 1.4.0:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/sdformat_1.4.0/sdf/1.4/world.sdf#world.sdf-16

I don't think gazebo has ever parsed joints directly under the world. The World::LoadEntities function certainly doesn't.

Have you ever seen one in a world file? I can add a note for it in the document, but I don't think it really counts as a legacy behavior if it's never actually been used.

content.raw:
I was super excited to see the “Parent frames in URDF” snippet, but then didn’t see how to make the poses exactly parallel.

Is it valid to squeeze that into this PR, and mention that it’s supported in the spec, but not yet via the software?

\(Also, is it possible to use concrete  - or even symbolic - values to indicate how specifying parent frames can help reduce the burden of doing manual forward kinematics?\)
content.html:
I was super excited to see the “Parent frames in URDF” snippet, but then didn’t see how to make the poses exactly parallel.

Is it valid to squeeze that into this PR, and mention that it’s supported in the spec, but not yet via the software?

(Also, is it possible to use concrete - or even symbolic - values to indicate how specifying parent frames can help reduce the burden of doing manual forward kinematics?)

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw:
Was this reversal intentional? Per Drake’s nomenclature, `X_AB` as a rigid transform implies that it transforms the basis from "w.r.t. B's frame" to "w.r.t. A's frame". As a pose, it implies "the pose of frame `B` w.r.t. frame `A`.”

Example: `p_A = X_AB * p_B`, where `p` implies the Cartesian position.

For clarify / specificity, we should also indicate that this frame relationship \+ monogram notation is only relevant to symbols / prefixes for SE\(3\) \+ SO\(3\) \(e.g. `X`, `rpy`, `xyz`, `R`\).
content.html:
Was this reversal intentional? Per Drake’s nomenclature, X_AB as a rigid transform implies that it transforms the basis from "w.r.t. B's frame" to "w.r.t. A's frame". As a pose, it implies "the pose of frame B w.r.t. frame A.”

Example: p_A = X_AB * p_B, where p implies the Cartesian position.

For clarify / specificity, we should also indicate that this frame relationship + monogram notation is only relevant to symbols / prefixes for SE(3) + SO(3) (e.g. X, rpy, xyz, R).

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw:
my mistake

I was intending to convey the same math: `p_A = X_AB * p_B` but got it backwards when converting to prose
content.html:
my mistake

I was intending to convey the same math: p_A = X_AB * p_B but got it backwards when converting to prose

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw:
Yup!  

\(But, uh, to nitpick, `from` and `to` but are kinda coupled to `X_AB` as a transform / operator and less as a pose... Usually something less coupling like `A` \+ `B` are safer for examples.\)
content.html:
Yup!

(But, uh, to nitpick, from and to but are kinda coupled to X_AB as a transform / operator and less as a pose... Usually something less coupling like A + B are safer for examples.)

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw:
Can we be more explicit with frames, and not try to delineate them via numbers and letters?

In Drake's monogram, you can use "subscripts" for a frame \(or just a lowercase letter\).

e.g. For calibration, we solve for `X_BC` \(pose of camera `C` w.r.t. `B` frame it's mounted to\) by measuring / estimating `X_WB` \(pose of `B` in world using fwd. kin\) `X_LCh` \(pose of checkerboard `Ch` w.r.t. `L` frame it's mounted to, using CAD measurements / fwd. kin\).

Example of what it could look like:

```
‌For brevity, we denote the frames `La` ("link_a"), `Lb` ("link_b"), and `Ja` ("joint_a").

We have poses `X_LaLb`, `X_JaLb`, [etc...]
```
content.html:
Can we be more explicit with frames, and not try to delineate them via numbers and letters?

In Drake's monogram, you can use "subscripts" for a frame (or just a lowercase letter).

e.g. For calibration, we solve for X_BC (pose of camera C w.r.t. B frame it's mounted to) by measuring / estimating X_WB (pose of B in world using fwd. kin) X_LCh (pose of checkerboard Ch w.r.t. L frame it's mounted to, using CAD measurements / fwd. kin).

Example of what it could look like:

‌For brevity, we denote the frames `La` ("link_a"), `Lb` ("link_b"), and `Ja` ("joint_a").

We have poses `X_LaLb`, `X_JaLb`, [etc...]

content.html:
I like using letters better than numbers, but I was working from the existing figure from the URDF documentation, which has the links numbered as Link1, Link2, etc.

I'll use L1, L2, J1 and give consistent frames to the SDF figure

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw: I understand this figure is showing that joint poses are defined relative to their child links. But I am concerned that it might add some confusion as readers compare this diagram with the URDF diagram. The red arrows point to the "middle" of the link ellipses suggesting that the link frame is located there. This makes it look different from the URDF figure in which the link frames are coincident with the joint frames. If the URDF and SDF are supposed to be equivalent, shouldn't the location of the link and joint frames be equivalent as well?
content.html: I understand this figure is showing that joint poses are defined relative to their child links. But I am concerned that it might add some confusion as readers compare this diagram with the URDF diagram. The red arrows point to the "middle" of the link ellipses suggesting that the link frame is located there. This makes it look different from the URDF figure in which the link frames are coincident with the joint frames. If the URDF and SDF are supposed to be equivalent, shouldn't the location of the link and joint frames be equivalent as well?

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw:
I agree that it may be confusing in its current state, but I want to be able to show visually how the frames are defined, and it's hard to see that if the child link and joint frames are collocated.

I'd rather keep the figures like this but add some explanatory text about why they are different. How does that sound?
content.html:
I agree that it may be confusing in its current state, but I want to be able to show visually how the frames are defined, and it's hard to see that if the child link and joint frames are collocated.

I'd rather keep the figures like this but add some explanatory text about why they are different. How does that sound?

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw:
My suggestion would be to create another example to demonstrate how the joint frame is defined relative to the child link. If you are saying the link frames are indeed in the middle of the ellipses, then the URDF and SDF are not equivalent. But this example is trying to demonstrate how we get equivalent representations in the two formats. 

In other words, if I run `gz sdf -p` on the URDF file, the output SDF file should have the joint and the link frames collocated (and it does). I was working out this example in Rviz and Gazebo to check the two:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<robot name="testrobot" xmlns:xacro="http://www.ros.org/wiki/xacro">
  <link name="link1">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint1" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 0' xyz='0.1 0.2 0'/>
    <parent link="link1"/>
    <child link="link2"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link2">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint2" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 1.5707963267948966' xyz='0 0.2 0'/>
    <parent link="link1"/>
    <child link="link3"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link3">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint3" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 -1.5707963267948966' xyz='0.2 0 0'/>
    <parent link="link3"/>
    <child link="link4"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link4">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>
</robot>
```

And here is equivalent SDF (using `gz sdf`). Notice that the joint tags don't have a `<pose>` element.

```
<sdf version='1.6'>
  <model name='testrobot'>
    <link name='link1'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <link name='link2'>
      <pose frame=''>0.1 0.2 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint1' type='revolute'>
      <child>link2</child>
      <parent>link1</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
    <link name='link3'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0.2 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint2' type='revolute'>
      <child>link3</child>
      <parent>link1</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
    <link name='link4'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0.4 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint3' type='revolute'>
      <child>link4</child>
      <parent>link3</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>
```
content.html:
My suggestion would be to create another example to demonstrate how the joint frame is defined relative to the child link. If you are saying the link frames are indeed in the middle of the ellipses, then the URDF and SDF are not equivalent. But this example is trying to demonstrate how we get equivalent representations in the two formats.

In other words, if I run gz sdf -p on the URDF file, the output SDF file should have the joint and the link frames collocated (and it does). I was working out this example in Rviz and Gazebo to check the two:

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<robot name="testrobot" xmlns:xacro="http://www.ros.org/wiki/xacro">
  <link name="link1">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint1" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 0' xyz='0.1 0.2 0'/>
    <parent link="link1"/>
    <child link="link2"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link2">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint2" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 1.5707963267948966' xyz='0 0.2 0'/>
    <parent link="link1"/>
    <child link="link3"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link3">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint3" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 -1.5707963267948966' xyz='0.2 0 0'/>
    <parent link="link3"/>
    <child link="link4"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link4">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>
</robot>

And here is equivalent SDF (using gz sdf). Notice that the joint tags don't have a <pose> element.

<sdf version='1.6'>
  <model name='testrobot'>
    <link name='link1'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <link name='link2'>
      <pose frame=''>0.1 0.2 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint1' type='revolute'>
      <child>link2</child>
      <parent>link1</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
    <link name='link3'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0.2 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint2' type='revolute'>
      <child>link3</child>
      <parent>link1</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
    <link name='link4'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0.4 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint3' type='revolute'>
      <child>link4</child>
      <parent>link3</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw: Have you seen my proposed changes to the model kinematics tutorial in pull request #8? There is a similar figure from the urdf documentation that only has 2 links and one joint. Is that comparison just as confusing as this one?
content.html: Have you seen my proposed changes to the model kinematics tutorial in pull request #8? There is a similar figure from the urdf documentation that only has 2 links and one joint. Is that comparison just as confusing as this one?

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw: No, that example is not as confusing because it doesn't explicitly state that the two models are equivalent. It might cause some confusion since the pictures are similar and the URDF example comes right after the SDF example. It might be good to mention somewhere that in order to create an SDF model that is equivalent to a URDF model, all joints should have `<pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>`. We could also use the example to show that changing the joint pose so it is different from the child link pose is only possible in SDF.
content.html: No, that example is not as confusing because it doesn't explicitly state that the two models are equivalent. It might cause some confusion since the pictures are similar and the URDF example comes right after the SDF example. It might be good to mention somewhere that in order to create an SDF model that is equivalent to a URDF model, all joints should have <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>. We could also use the example to show that changing the joint pose so it is different from the child link pose is only possible in SDF.

<link name="link1">

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw:
Question: I've seen `sdf` and `SDFormat` used interchangeably, but I’m still confused:

Which is the specification, and which is the software? If they’re ambiguous, we should make a task at some point to disambiguate them.
content.html:
Question: I've seen sdf and SDFormat used interchangeably, but I’m still confused:

Which is the specification, and which is the software? If they’re ambiguous, we should make a task at some point to disambiguate them.

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw: that's a good question; both the spec and the osrf reference parser implementation are stored in the same repository named `sdformat`. I would propose using `libsdformat` to refer to the reference parser and either sdf or SDFormat to refer to the specification.
content.html: that's a good question; both the spec and the osrf reference parser implementation are stored in the same repository named sdformat. I would propose using libsdformat to refer to the reference parser and either sdf or SDFormat to refer to the specification.
